Directions
This simulation plots the trajectory of a non-rotating sphere when launched; the surface roughness determines the sphere's drag profile. First, select the surface roughness using the drop-down menu,
where \( \large{ \varepsilon } \) is the depth of imperfections and \( \small{ D } \) is the sphere's diameter. Then, choose a launch angle and launch velocity using the sliders:
then press . After the sphere has landed, you may press "Launch" again with different settings to compare trajectories on the same plot. Otherwise, press to clear the previous trajectories.
The drag coefficient is displayed as a white circle on both plots. The shape of the "Reynold's Number versus Drag Coefficient" curve depends on the sphere's roughness.
Details
For an object in motion, there are three relevant forces acting on it. The gravitational force \( F_{g} \), the drag force \( F_{D} \), and the lift force \( F_{L} \):
The gravitational force \( F_{g} = gm \) is a function of the object's mass \( m \) and gravitational acceleration \( g \). The lift force \( F_{L} \) is defined as $$ F_{L} = \frac{ C_{L} \rho V^{2} A_{c} }{ 2 } $$ Where \( \rho \) is the fluid density, \( A_{c} \) is the cross-sectional area of the object, \( V \) is the velocity of the object, and \( C_{L} \) is the lift coefficient. For spheres, \( C_{L} \) is a function of angular velocity (rotation speed), Reynold's number \( Re = \frac{ \rho V D }{ \mu } \) (with \( \mu \) being dynamic viscosity of the fluid), angle of attack \( \theta \), and geometry of the sphere. A golf ball's geometry to maximizes \( F_{L} \) when the ball is rotating, to make it fly further. Since this simulation assumes zero angular velocity, \( F_{L} \) is zero. The drag equation is nearly identical, $$ F_{D} = \frac{ C_{D} \rho V^{2} A_{c} }{ 2 } $$ with the drag coefficient \( C_{D} \) being a function of the Reynold's number, angular velocity, and geometry of the sphere. Surface roughness has a large effect on the drag coefficient, with golf balls being designed to minimize \( C_{D} \) at low velocities.
